Automapper ignore properties while mapping a list
items.detail: Normally you should never map lists or collections. You map the classes and AutoMapper takes care of the rest.

items.title: C# Asp.net Web API - creating a JSON/XML converter API
items.detail: Could you show the response you get from the server in Fiddler?

items.title: C# Asp.net Web API - creating a JSON/XML converter API
items.detail: By default, when you create a new application using the wizard they are placed in `~/App_Start/WebApiConfig.cs`. Also from your Fiddler screenshot I can see that you have provided invalid JSON payload: `{sample:"true"}`. A valid JSON should look like this: `{"sample":"true"}`.

items.title: Automapper ignore properties while mapping a list
C# Asp.net Web API - creating a JSON/XML converter API
items.detail: No, you have shown your MVC routes setup not your Web API routes. Those are 2 completely different things. Also you cannot expect to get the POST request payload into a variable called `jsonOrXml` in your Post action. You will have to read it from the request body. It won't come as parameter. Or if you want it to you will have to write a custom model binder or formatter.

items.title: C# Asp.net Web API - creating a JSON/XML converter API
items.detail: How are you calling this action? Could you show your client code? Also please show your current routes setup.

items.detail: Nope it won't work. But it's easy to implement. You will have to hook up to the client side validation and hide the corresponding label on the client.

Stress test my site
items.detail: Try running load tests with `JMeter`. If the results are not expected then the problem is in the service you are testing. If the results are expected then the problem is in the `RunStressParrallelTest` method or the way you are running/using it. If this is the case we could discuss it.

items.title: Make a specific controller grab views from a subfolder
items.detail: You will have to write a custom view engine to achieve this.

items.title: L2S association property (IEnumerable) in Model being cleared from one call of RenderAction to next
items.detail: In the `//do some things` section of your Partial controller action maybe you are doing some things that you shouldn't be doing or which would explain the behavior you are observing :-) What happened when you removed everything from this action and left only the `return View(model);` in it? Are you still observing the same behavior?

items.title: Stress test my site
items.detail: While I didn't downvote the question, I agree with the person that did it. There's very little information provided here. Usage of things like `BetterWebClient`, missing information about how many threads, clients are being requested, what are the expected results, how the actual results differ from the expected results, ...
